{{multiple issues| {{Underlinked|date=May 2014}} {{Orphan|date=May 2014}} {{technical|date=June 2014}} }} In physics, the '''total position-spread (TPS)''' [[tensor]] is a quantity originally introduced in the modern theory of [[electrical conductivity]]. In the case of molecular systems, this tensor measures the fluctuation of the electrons around their mean positions, which corresponds to the delocalization of the electronic charge within a molecular system. The TPS can discriminate between metals and insulators taking information from the ground state [[wave function]]. This quantity can be very useful as an indicator to characterize [[Intervalence charge transfer]] processes, the bond nature of molecules (covalent, ionic or weakly bonded), and [[Metal–insulator transition]].
==Overview==
The Localization Tensor (LT) is a ''per electron'' quantity proposed in the context of the theory of [[Walter Kohn|Kohn]]<ref>{{cite journal |author=W. Kohn |title=Theory of the Insulating State |journal=Phys. Rev. |volume=133 |issue= 1A |pages=A171–A181 |year= 1964|pmid= |doi=10.1103/PhysRev.133.A171|bibcode = 1964PhRv..133..171K }}</ref> to characterize electrical conductivity properties. In 1964, Kohn realized that electrical conductivity is more related to the proper delocalization of the wave function than a simple band gap. In fact, he proposed that a qualitative difference between [[Insulator (electricity)|insulators]] and [[Electrical conductor|conductors]] also manifests as a different organization of the electrons in their ground state where one has that: the wave function is strongly localized in insulators and very delocalized in conductors.
The interesting outcome of this theory is: ''i)'' it relates the classical idea of localized electrons as a cause of insulating state; ''ii)'' the needed information can be recovered from the ground state wave function because in the insulated regime the wave function breaks down as a sum of disconnected terms.
It is until 1999 that Resta and coworkers <ref>{{cite journal |author1=R. Resta |author2=S. Sorella |title=Electron Localization in the Insulating State |journal=Phys. Rev. Lett. |volume=82 |issue= 2 |pages=370 |year= 1999|pmid= |doi=10.1103/PhysRevLett.82.370|arxiv = cond-mat/9808151 |bibcode = 1999PhRvL..82..370R }}</ref> found a way to define the Kohn delocalization by proposing the already mentioned Localization Tensor. The LT is defined as a second order moment cumulant of the position operator divided by the number of electrons in the system. The key property of the LT is that: it diverges for metals while it takes finite values for insulators in the [[Thermodynamic limit]].
Recently, the global quantity (the LT not divided by the number of electrons) has been introduced to study molecules and named Total Position-Spread tensor.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=O. Brea |author2=M. El Khatib |author3=C. Angeli |author4=G.L. Bendazzoli |author5=S. Evangelisti |author6=T. Leininger |title=Behavior of the Position–Spread Tensor in Diatomic Systems |journal=J. Chem. Theory Comput. |volume=9 |issue= 12 |pages=5286–5295 |year= 2013|pmid= 26592266|doi=10.1021/ct400453b}}</ref>
== Theory ==
=== Spin-summed TPS, (SS-TPS) === The total position spread '''Λ''' is defined as the second [[Moment (physics)|moment]] [[cumulant]] of the total electron [[position operator]], and its units are in length square (e.g. bohr²). In order to compute this quantity, one has to take into account the position operator and its tensorial square.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=M. El Khatib |author2=T. Leininger |author3=G. L. Bendazzoli |author4=S. Evangelisti |title=Computing the Position-Spread Tensor in the CAS-SCF formalism |journal=Chem. Phys. Lett. |volume=591 |issue= 2 |pages=58 |year= 2014|pmid= |doi=10.1016/j.cplett.2013.10.080|bibcode = 2014CPL...591...58E }}</ref> For a system of ''n'' electrons, the position operator and its Cartesian components are defined as:
: <math>\mathbf{\hat{r}} = \sum_{i=1}^n \hat{r}_i</math> (total position)
: <math>\hat{x} = \sum_{i=1}^n \hat{x}_i \qquad \hat{y} = \sum_{i=1}^n \hat{y}_i \qquad \hat{z} = \sum_{i=1}^n \hat{z}_i \qquad</math>
Where the ''i'' index runs over the number of electrons. Each component of the position operator is a one-electron operator, they can be represented in second quantization as follows:
: <math>\hat{x}= \sum_{ij} \left \langle i\mid \hat{x}\mid j\right \rangle a^{\dagger}_i a_j</math>
where ''i'',''j'' run over orbitals. The expectation values of the position components are the first moments of the electrons' position.
Now we consider the tensorial square (second moment). In this sense, there are two types of them:
* in [[quantum chemistry]] programs like [[MOLPRO]] or DALTON the second moment operator is a tensor defined as the sum of the tensor squares of the positions of a single electron. Then, this is a one-electron operator ''s'' defined by its Cartesian components:
:: <math>\hat{s}_{xx}=\sum_{i=1}^n \hat{x}_i^2 \qquad \hat{s}_{xy}=\sum_{i=1}^n \hat{x} \hat{y}\qquad \hat{s}_{xz}=\sum_{i=1}^n \hat{x} \hat{z} </math>
:: <math>\hat{s}_{yy}=\sum_{i=1}^n \hat{y}_i^2 \qquad \hat{s}_{yz}=\sum_{i=1}^n \hat{y} \hat{z}\qquad \hat{s}_{zz}=\sum_{i=1}^n \hat{z}_i^2 </math>
: where index ''i'' runs over the number of electrons. * there is also the square of the total position operator <math>\hat{r}</math>. This is a two-electron operator ''S'', and also defined by its Cartesian components:
:: <math>\hat{S}_{xx}=\sum_{i=1}^n \sum_{j=1}^n \hat{x}_i \hat{x}_j \qquad \hat{S}_{xy}=\sum_{i=1}^n \sum_{j=1}^n \hat{x}_i \hat{y}_j \qquad \hat{S}_{xz}=\sum_{i=1}^n \sum_{j=1}^n\hat{x}_i \hat{z}_j </math>
:: <math>\hat{S}_{yy}=\sum_{i=1}^n \sum_{j=1}^n \hat{y}_i\hat{y}_j \qquad \hat{S}_{yz}=\sum_{i=1}^n \sum_{j=1}^n \hat{y}_i \hat{z}_j\qquad \hat{S}_{zz}=\sum_{i=1}^n\sum_{j=1}^n \hat{z}_i \hat{z}_j </math>
: where indices ''i'',''j'' run over electrons.
The second moment of the position becomes then the sum of the one- and two-electron operators already defined:
:<math> \mathbf{S}_{ab} = \mathbf{\hat{S}}_{ab} + \mathbf{\hat{s}}_{ab}</math>
Given a ''n''-electron wave function <math>\Psi</math>, one wants to compute the ''second moment cumulant'' of it. A cumulant is a linear combination of moments so we have:
: <math>\Lambda = \left \langle \Psi\mid S_{ab}\mid\Psi\right \rangle_c = \left \langle \Psi\mid S_{ab}\mid\Psi\right \rangle - \left \langle \Psi\mid\hat{a}\mid\Psi\right \rangle \left \langle \Psi\mid\hat{b}\mid\Psi\right \rangle</math>
=== Spin-partitioned TPS, (SP-TPS) ===
The position operator can be partitioned according to spin components.
: <math>\mathbf{\hat r} = \sum_{\sigma = \alpha,\beta} \mathbf{\hat r_{\sigma}}</math>
From the one-particle operator it is possible to define the total spin-partitioned position operator as:
:<math>\mathbf{\hat R} = \sum_{i=1}^n \sum_{\sigma=\alpha,\beta} \mathbf{\hat R}(i) \mathbf{\hat n}_\sigma(i)</math>
Therefore, the total position operator <math>\mathbf{\hat R}</math> can be expressed by the sum of the two spin parts <math>\alpha</math> and <math>\beta</math>:
:<math>\mathbf{\hat R} = \mathbf{\hat R_{\alpha}} + \mathbf{\hat R_{\beta}}</math>
and the square of the total position operator decomposes as:
:<math>\mathbf{\hat R}^2 = \mathbf{\hat R}_{\alpha}^2 + \mathbf{\hat R}_{\beta}^2 + \mathbf{\hat R}_{\alpha} \mathbf{\hat R}_{\beta} + \mathbf{\hat R}_{\beta} \mathbf{\hat R}_{\alpha}</math>
Thus, there are four joint second moment cumulant of the spin-partitioned position operator:
:<math>\mathbf{\Lambda} = \mathbf{\Lambda}_{\alpha\alpha} + \mathbf{\Lambda}_{\beta\beta} + \mathbf{ \Lambda}_{\alpha\beta} + \mathbf{\Lambda}_{\beta\alpha}</math>
==Applications==
===Model Hamiltonians===
====Hubbard model==== [[File:HubbardTPS.png|thumbnail|Figure 1: SS-TPS as a function of the ''-t/U'' ratio is computed numerically for equally-spaced 1D chains of hydrogen atoms.]] The [[Hubbard model]] is a very simple and approximate model employed in [[Condensed matter physics]] to describe the transition of materials from metals to insulators. It takes into account only two parameters: ''i)'' the kinetic energy or hopping integral denoted by ''-t''; and ''ii)'' the on-site repulsion between electrons represented by ''U'' (see the [[Hubbard model#Example: 1D chain of hydrogen atoms|example for 1D chain of hydrogen atoms]]).
In Figure 1, there are two limit cases to consider: larger values of ''-t/U'' representing a strong charge fluctuation (electrons free to move) whereas for small values of ''-t/U'' the electrons are completely localized. The SS-TPS is very sensitive to these changes, because it increases faster than linearly when electrons start to present mobility (0.0 to 0.5 range of ''-t/U'').
====Heisenberg model==== <!-- [[File:HeisTPS.png|thumbnail|Figure 2: ]] -->
=== Monitor the wave function === [[File:H2TPS.png|thumbnail|Figure 3: SS-TPS as a function of the internuclear distance R for the hydrogen dimer.]] The TPS is a powerful tool to monitor the wave function. In Figure 3 is shown the longitudinal SS-TPS ('''Λ<sup>∥</sup>''') computed at [[full configuration interaction]] level for the H<sub>2</sub> diatomic molecule. The '''Λ<sup>∥</sup>''' in the high repulsive region shows a value that is lower than in the asymptotic limit. This is a consequence of nuclei being near to each other's causing and enhancement of the effective nuclear charge that makes electrons to be more localized. When stretching the bond, the TPS starts growing until it reaches a maximum (strong delocalization of the wave function) before the bond is broken. Once the bond is broken, the wave function becomes a sum of disconnected localized regions and the tensor decreases until it reaches twice the value of the atomic limit (1 bohr² for each hydrogen atom).
=== Spin delocalization === [[File:H2SPTPS.png|thumbnail|Figure 4: SP-TPS as a function of the internuclear distance R for the hydrogen dimer.]] When the total position-spread tensor is partitioned according to spin (SP-TPS), it becomes a powerful tool to describe spin delocalization in the insulating regime. In Figure 4 is shown the longitudinal SP-TPS ('''Λ<sup>∥</sup>''') computed at [[full configuration interaction]] level for the H<sub>2</sub> diatomic molecule. The horizontal line at 0 bohr<sup>2</sup> divides the same spin (positive values) and different spin (negative values) contributions of the spin partitioned TPS. Unlike the SS-TPS that saturates to the atomic value for R>5, the SP-TPS diverges as R<sup>2</sup> indicating that there is a strong spin delocalization. The SP-TPS can also be seen as a measure of how strong the electron correlation is.
== Properties ==
The TPS is a cumulant<ref>{{cite journal |author=R. Kubo |title=Generalized cumulant expansion method |journal=Journal of the Physical Society of Japan |volume=17 |issue= 7 |pages=1100–1120 |year= 1962|pmid= |doi=10.1143/JPSJ.17.1100|bibcode = 1962JPSJ...17.1100K }}</ref> and thus it possesses the following properties:
# Cumulants can be explicitly represented only by moments of lower or equal order. # Cumulants are a linear combination of the products of these moments of lower or equal order. # Cumulants are additive. This is a very important property when studying molecular systems because it means that the TPS tensor shows size consistency. # A diagonal element of the cumulant tensor is the [[variance]] (see also [[Measurement in quantum mechanics#Statistics of measurement|this article]]), and it is always a positive value. # Cumulants also are invariant under translation of the origin of when they are of order ≥ 2. The TPS tensor being a second-order culumant, is invariant under translation of the origin. # The TPS is more sensitive to the variation of the [[wave function]] than the energy, which makes it a good indicator for instance in a [[Metal–insulator transition]] situation.

[[File:Traite-Pyrenees.jpg|thumb|250px|Louis XIV of France and Philip IV of Spain at the [[Meeting on the Isle of Pheasants]] in June 1660]] [[File:Tratado Pirineos 1659.jpg|250px|thumb|right|The geopolitical effects of the Treaty of Pyrenees (1659)]]
The '''Treaty of the Pyrenees''' ({{lang-fr|Traité des Pyrénées}}, {{lang-es|Tratado de los Pirineos}}, {{lang-ca|Tractat dels Pirineus}}, {{lang-pt|Tratado dos Pirenéus}}) was signed on 7 November 1659 to end the [[Franco-Spanish War (1635–59)|1635–1659 war]] between [[France]] and [[Spain]],<ref name="Cooper1979">{{cite book|author=J. P. Cooper|title=The New Cambridge Modern History: Volume 4, The Decline of Spain and the Thirty Years War, 1609-48/49|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gbU8AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA428|date=20 December 1979|publisher=CUP Archive|isbn=978-0-521-29713-4|page=428}}</ref> a war that was initially a part of the wider [[Thirty Years' War]]. It was signed on [[Pheasant Island]], a river island on the border between the two countries which has remained a French-Spanish [[condominium (international law)|condominium]] since the treaty. The kings [[Louis XIV of France]] and [[Philip IV of Spain]] were represented by their chief ministers, [[Cardinal Mazarin]] and Don [[Luis Méndez de Haro]], respectively.<ref name="Sahlins1989">{{cite book|author=Peter Sahlins|title=Boundaries: The Making of France and Spain in the Pyrenees|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=WPLEOKM1CI8C&pg=PA25|year=1989|publisher=University of California Press|isbn=978-0-520-91121-5|page=25}}</ref>
==Background==
France entered the Thirty Years' War after the [[Spanish Habsburg]] victories in the [[Dutch Revolt]] in the 1620s and at the [[Battle of Nördlingen (1634)|Battle of Nördlingen]] against [[Sweden]] in 1634. By 1640, France began to interfere in Spanish politics, aiding the [[Reapers' War|revolt in Catalonia]], while Spain responded by aiding the [[Fronde]] revolt in France in 1648. During the negotiations for the [[Peace of Westphalia]] in 1648, France gained the [[Sundgau]] and cut off Spanish access to the [[Netherlands]] from [[Austria]], leading to open warfare between the French and Spanish.
After 23 years of war, an Anglo-French alliance was victorious at the [[Battle of the Dunes (1658)|Battle of the Dunes]] in June 14, 1658, but the following year the war ground to a halt when the French campaign to take [[Milan]] was defeated. Peace was settled by means of the Treaty of the Pyrenees in November 1659.
==Content== [[File:Ignoto (forse jean hardy), luigi XIV e filippo IV di spagna, pace dei pirenei, 1660.JPG|thumb|Medal celebrating the Treaty (1660)]]
France gained [[Roussillon]] (including [[Perpignan]]) and the northern half of [[Cerdanya]], [[Montmédy]] and other parts of [[Luxembourg]], [[Artois]] and other towns in [[Flanders]], including Arras, [[Béthune]], [[Gravelines]] and [[Thionville]], and a new border with Spain was fixed at the Pyrenees.<ref name=pyrconditions>{{cite book|last=Maland M.A.|first=David|title=Europe in the Seventeenth Century|publisher=Macmillan|year=1991|edition=Second |pages=227|isbn=0-333-33574-0}}</ref> However, the treaty stipulated only that all "villages" north of the Pyrenees should become part of France. Because it was a villa, the historic town of [[Llívia]], once the capital of Cerdanya, was thus unintentionally exempted from the treaty and became a Spanish exclave as part of the ''[[comarca]]'' of [[Baixa Cerdanya]], in the [[Spanish provinces|Spanish province]] of [[Girona (province)|Girona]]. This border was not properly settled until the [[France–Spain border|Treaty of Bayonne]] was signed in 1856, with its final acts accepted 12 years later. On the western Pyrenees a definite borderline was drawn and decisions made as to the politico-administrative affiliation of bordering areas in the Basque region—[[Baztan (valley)|Baztan]], [[Aldude]], [[Valcarlos]].
Spain was forced to recognize and confirm all of the French gains at the Peace of Westphalia.<ref name=pyrconditions/>
In exchange for the Spanish territorial losses, the French king pledged to quit his support for [[Portugal]] and renounced to his claim to the [[county of Barcelona]], which the French crown had claimed ever since the [[Reapers' War|Catalan Revolt]] (also known as Reapers' War).<ref name=pyrconditions/> The Portuguese revolt in 1640, led by the Duke of Braganza, was supported monetarily by Cardinal Richelieu of France. After the Catalan Revolt, France had controlled the [[Principality of Catalonia]] from January 1641, when a combined Catalan and French force defeated the Spanish army at [[Battle of Montjuïc (1641)|Battle of Montjuïc]], until it was defeated by a Spanish army at Barcelona in 1652.<ref name="Pendrillrevolts">{{cite book|last=Pendrill|first=Colin|title=Spain 1474 - 1700|editor=Martin Collier, Erica Lewis |publisher=Heinemann Advanced History, The Triumphs and Tribulations of Empire |year=2002|pages=142–143|isbn=978-0-435-32733-0}}</ref> Though the Spanish army reconquered most of Catalonia, the French retained Catalan territory north of the Pyrenees.
The treaty also arranged for a marriage between [[Louis XIV of France]] and [[Maria Theresa of Spain]], the daughter of [[Philip IV of Spain]].<ref name=pyrconditions/> Maria Theresa was forced to renounce her claim to the Spanish throne, in return for a monetary settlement as part of her [[dowry]]. This settlement was never paid, a factor that eventually led to the [[War of Devolution]] in 1668. At the [[Meeting on the Isle of Pheasants]] in June 1660, the two monarchs and their ministers met, and the princess entered France.
In addition, the English received [[Dunkirk]],<ref name=pyrconditions/> although they elected to sell it to France in 1662.
==Consequences== The Treaty of the Pyrenees was the last major diplomatic achievement by Cardinal Mazarin. Combined with the [[Peace of Westphalia]], it allowed Louis XIV remarkable stability and diplomatic advantage by means of a weakened [[Louis II de Bourbon, Prince de Condé]] and a weakened Spanish Crown, along with the agreed dowry, which was an important element in the French king's strategy: [[Image:Catalonia2.png|200px|thumb|Map of [[Catalonia]], showing the partition of its territory by means of the Treaty of the Pyrenees.]] All in all, by 1660, when the [[Deluge (history)|Swedish occupation of Poland]] was over, most of the European continent was at peace ([[Portuguese Restoration War]], third stage), and the Bourbons had ended the dominance of the [[Habsburgs]].<ref name="Cooper1979431–432">{{cite book|author=J. P. Cooper|title=The New Cambridge Modern History: Volume 4, The Decline of Spain and the Thirty Years War, 1609-48/49|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=gbU8AAAAIAAJ&pg=PA431|date=20 December 1979|publisher=CUP Archive|isbn=978-0-521-29713-4|pages=431–432}}</ref><ref name="Oakley2005">{{cite book|author=Stewart P. Oakley|title=War and Peace in the Baltic, 1560-1790|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=BmyIAgAAQBAJ&pg=PA84|date=28 June 2005|publisher=Routledge|isbn=978-1-134-97451-1|pages=84–85}}</ref> In the Pyrenees, the treaty resulted in the establishment of border customs and restriction of the free cross-border flow of people and goods.
===French annexations===
In the context of the territorial changes involved in the Treaty, France gained some territory, on both its northern and southern borders.
*In the north, France gained [[French Flanders]]. *In the south: ::# On the east: The northern part of the [[Principality of Catalonia]], including [[Roussillon]], [[Conflent]], [[Vallespir]], [[Capcir]], and [[French Cerdagne]], was transferred to France, i.e. what later came to be known as "[[Northern Catalonia]]". ::# On the west: The parties agree to put together a field group to compromise a borderline on disputed lands along the Basque Pyrenees, involving Sareta—[[Zugarramurdi]], [[Ainhoa, Pyrénées-Atlantiques|Ainhoa]], etc.— [[Aldude]], and the Spanish wedge of [[Valcarlos]].

{{Infobox recurring event | name = World Woman | native_name = | logo = World Woman .jpg | logo_caption = Official Logo | date = | begins = | ends = | prev = | next = | frequency = | location = | years_active = | founded = 2015 ([[Oslo]], [[Norway]]) | last = | participants = | attendance = | genre = | budget = | patron = | organised = [[Fuuse]] | website = | footnotes = }}
'''WORLD WOMAN''' is a festival of art and activism in [[Oslo]] founded in 2015 by filmmaker and activist [[Deeyah Khan]]. The festival highlights the voices of artists and activists from around the world and promotes courage, creativity and compassion through human rights, freedom of expression, equality and peace.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Khan|first1=Deeyah|title=Violence is the real provocation, not speech |url=https://www.theguardian.com/lifeandstyle/she-said/2015/jan/24/violence-is-the-real-provocation-not-speech|work=The Guardian|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref> The event was produced by [[Fuuse]] and it took place on the 30th and 31 January 2015 in the Riksscenen with the support of Norway's [[Ministry of Foreign Affairs (Norway)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]]. WORLD WOMAN is planned as an annual event.
==2015 event== World Woman 2015 theme was Courage and Creativity.
The inaugural World Woman festival featured performances by [[Mari Boine]], [[Marilyn Mazur]], [[John McLaughlin (musician)|John McLaughlin]], [[Mahsa Vahdat]], [[Sister Fa]], Pakistani dancer [[Sheema Kermani]], founder of [[Tehrik-e-Niswan]], [[Fahmida Riaz]], [[Viktoria Mullova]], [[Gary Husband]], [[Bugge Wesseltoft]], [[Eivind Aarset]], [[Hela Fattoumi]], [[Arve Henriksen]].
World Woman conversations and talks included [[Shirin Ebadi]], [[Nawal El Saadawi]], [[Hina Jilani]], [[Sanam Naraghi-Anderlini]], International Civil Society Action Network (ICAN), [[Gro Brundtland]], [[Scilla Elworthy]], [[Şafak Pavey]], [[Mona Eltahawy]], [[Gurpreet Kaur Bhatti]], [[Kenan Malik]], [[Ayşe Önal]], [[Sister Rosemary Nyirumbe]], [[Fawzia Koofi]], [[Farida Shaheed]], [[Natalia Koliada]] of [[Belarus Free Theatre]], [[Leyla Hussein]], [[Yanar Mohammed]], [[Gabrielle Rifkind]], [[Rana Husseini]].
Messages of support and solidarity were recorded by [[Patrick Stewart]], [[Erna Solberg]], [[Sinead O'Connor]], [[Kofi Annan]], [[Sting (musician)|Sting]] and [[Richard Branson]].
=== Coverage === WORLD WOMAN was covered in ''[[Volkskrant]]'', ''[[The Guardian]]'', ''[[Huffington Post]]'', ''[[The Independent]]''<ref>{{cite web|last1=Attwood|first1=Karen|title=World Woman Festival 2015: Women in countries such as Iraq, Syria and Afghanistan 'worst hit' by fundamentalism|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/politics/world-woman-festival-2015-women-in-countries-such-as-iraq-syria-and-afghanistan-worst-hit-by-fundamentalism-10016095.html|website=The Independent|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref> and on BBC4's ''[[Woman's Hour]]''<ref>{{cite web|title=The NHS, Film-Maker Deeyah Khan, Women in Construction|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b0510b6v|website=BBC Radio 4}}</ref> as well as the Norwegian press.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Fuglehaug|first1=Wensche|title=Deeyah Khan:"Jeg vet hvordan det føles å stå alene, å være ingen..."|url=http://www.osloby.no/nyheter/Jeg-vet-hvordan-det-foles-a-sta-alene_-a-vare-ingen-7879007.html|publisher=Osloby|accessdate=8 February 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Deeyah Khan Stirs Debate in Oslo|url=http://www.newsinenglish.no/2015/01/30/deeyah-khan-spurs-dialogue-in-oslo/|website=News in English}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Henrikson|first1=Arve|title=Samler kvinnelige stemmer til samtale og musikk|url=http://www.aftenposten.no/kultur/Samler-kvinnelige-stemmer-til-samtale-og-musikk-7796491.html|website=Aftenposten}}</ref>
